key_points: Nearly three weeks post-Hurricane Ida, New Orleans faces slow trash pickup recovery, with some areas not serviced since the storm.
Labor issues and a national labor shortage have been cited as reasons for the slow collection process.
Mayor LaToya Cantrell announced residents could dispose of trash at Elysian Fields Transfer Station starting from Sept. 16, 2021.
Metro Service Group, the city's trash collection agency, had been lagging in collections even before Hurricane Ida.
Workers for the agency had previously gone on strike in May 2020 requesting higher wages and COVID-19 protection equipment.
To address staffing challenges, the city contracted additional waste companies and extended existing contracts to find more bidders.
Residents are frustrated with the delays, with some taking personal steps to manage and dispose of their trash.
The labor dispute from the previous year is remembered, highlighting ongoing issues with fair compensation for trash collectors.
A 'Trash Parade' protest has been scheduled, while City Council members seek solutions through a joint Public Works and Budget Committees meeting.
Mayor Cantrell's pre-Ida claim of emergency preparedness has come under scrutiny amid current trash collection delays.
